question_text: Explain Ruby's object model and how method lookup works
explanation: Method lookup: 1) Singleton class methods 2) Class methods 3) Included modules (last included first) 4) Superclass chain. Use .ancestors to see lookup chain.

question_text: What are Ruby fibers and how do they differ from threads?
explanation: resume
topic: Fibers are lightweight concurrency primitives for cooperative multitasking. Unlike threads
mdn_link: they must explicitly yield control. Use Fiber.yield and Fiber#resume.

question_text: Explain Ruby's memory model and garbage collection algorithm
explanation: marking
mdn_link: Ruby 2.1+ uses generational GC with major/minor collections. Objects start in young generation
youtube_english: promoted after surviving collections. Uses tri-color marking.

question_text: What is Ruby's constant lookup algorithm?
explanation: ancestors
topic: Constants lookup: 1) Lexical scope 2) Inheritance chain 3) Object space. Use :: for absolute lookup. Modules included in ancestors also searched.

question_text: Explain Ruby's method binding and unbinding
explanation: Method#unbind
topic: Method objects can be unbound from original receiver and bound to new objects. Useful for dynamic dispatch: method.unbind.bind(new_receiver).call.

question_text: What are Ruby refinements and their limitations?
explanation: Refinements modify classes only in specific scope via 'using'. Limitations: 1) File scope 2) Not dynamic 3) No module inclusion refinement.

question_text: Explain Ruby's tracepoint API for debugging
explanation: call tracing
topic: TracePoint hooks into Ruby execution: call
youtube_kannada: etc. Use TracePoint.trace { |tp| ... }. Be careful of performance.

question_text: What is Ruby's Ractor model and thread safety?
explanation: shareable objects
topic: Ractors are Ruby's actor implementation for true parallelism. Each ractor has isolated objects; share only immutable or specially marked objects.

question_text: Explain Ruby's parser and AST manipulation
explanation: abstract syntax tree
topic: Ruby's Ripper module provides access to parser and AST. Use Ripper.sexp(raw_code) to get AST. Useful for code analysis and transformation.

question_text: What are Ruby's enumerators and lazy evaluation?
explanation: external iteration
topic: Enumerators decouple iteration from data. Lazy enumerators enable infinite sequences and chained operations without intermediate arrays.

question_text: Explain Ruby's method caching and inline caching
explanation: Ruby caches method lookups in inline caches at call sites. Global method cache invalidated on method definition. Use #prepend to see cache effects.

question_text: What is Ruby's binding of caller?
explanation: Requires binding_of_caller gem. Accesses binding of calling method. Powerful but dangerous - can modify caller's locals.

question_text: Explain Ruby's autoload and zeitwerk constant loading
explanation: load
topic: Autoload defers loading until constant accessed. Zeitwerk (Rails 6+) is modern autoloader with explicit conventions and thread safety.

question_text: What are Ruby's finalizers and their risks?
correct_answer: Finalizers run before object GC. Risks: 1) Can resurrect objects 2) Execution order undefined 3) Not guaranteed to run.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/ObjectSpace.html#method-c-define_finalizer

question_text: Explain Ruby's coverage module for code analysis
explanation: Ruby's Coverage module measures code execution. Use Coverage.start and Coverage.result. Supports line and branch coverage in Ruby 3.

question_text: What is Ruby's prepend and how differs from include?
explanation: ancestors
topic: Prepend inserts module before class in ancestors chain. Include inserts after. Prepend overrides class methods

question_text: Explain Ruby's method_added and singleton_method_added hooks
explanation: These hooks fire when methods defined. method_added for instance methods

question_text: What is Ruby's UnboundMethod and its use cases?
explanation: UnboundMethod is method not bound to object. Can bind to compatible objects. Useful for delegation patterns and dynamic dispatch.

question_text: Explain Ruby's instance_eval vs class_eval
explanation: self modification
mdn_link: class_eval opens class context. instance_eval defines singleton methods

question_text: What are Ruby's refinements and why were they introduced?
explanation: Refinements allow controlled monkey patching scoped to specific files/modules. Introduced to solve global namespace pollution from open classes.

question_text: Explain Ruby's ObjectSpace and its performance implications
explanation: ObjectSpace allows iteration over all live objects. Heavy performance impact - triggers full GC. Use only for debugging/profiling.

question_text: What is Ruby's Marshal module and security considerations?
explanation: remote code execution
topic: Marshal serializes Ruby objects. Security risk: loading untrusted data can execute arbitrary code. Use with trusted data only.

question_text: Explain Ruby's GC::Profiler and memory profiling
explanation: GC::Profiler provides GC statistics. Use GC::Profiler.enable and GC::Profiler.report. Also ObjectSpace.trace_object_allocations.

question_text: What are Ruby's thread variables and thread-local storage?
explanation: Thread.current[:var] for thread-local
topic: Thread.current.thread_variable_set for fiber-local. Fiber-local variables inherited by child fibers.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Queue and SizedQueue for thread communication
explanation: Queue is thread-safe FIFO. SizedQueue has fixed capacity
topic: blocks when full. Use for producer-consumer patterns.

question_text: What is Ruby's DRb and distributed objects?
explanation: DRb allows objects in different Ruby processes to communicate. Uses Marshal for serialization. Security concerns with untrusted networks.

question_text: Explain Ruby's singleton class (eigenclass) inheritance
explanation: Singleton classes inherit from object's class. Each object has unique singleton class. Class methods live in class's singleton class.

question_text: What are Ruby's private and protected visibility rules?
explanation: method visibility
topic: Private: can only be called with implicit receiver. Protected: can be called by any instance of same class or descendants.

question_text: Explain Ruby's method_missing and respond_to_missing
explanation: method_missing catches undefined methods. Must override respond_to_missing? for consistency. Use for DSLs and delegation.

question_text: What is Ruby's REXML and Nokogiri for XML parsing?
explanation: XPath
topic: REXML is Ruby's built-in XML parser. Nokogiri is faster
mdn_link: C-based alternative with XPath/CSS support. Use Nokogiri for production.

question_text: Explain Ruby's BigDecimal for precise decimal arithmetic
explanation: BigDecimal provides arbitrary precision decimal arithmetic. Avoids floating point errors for financial calculations.

question_text: What are Ruby's Set and SortedSet collections?
explanation: hash-based sets
topic: Set stores unique elements using hash. SortedSet maintains order using red-black tree. Requires 'set' require.

question_text: Explain Ruby's CSV parsing with headers and converters
explanation: encoding
youtube_english: and encoding. Use CSV.foreach for streaming

question_text: What is Ruby's OpenStruct and its performance considerations?
explanation: OpenStruct creates objects with dynamic attributes using method_missing. Slower than Struct or Hash. Good for prototyping.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Date
explanation: Time
youtube_hindi: Date: calendar date. Time: seconds since epoch with timezone. DateTime: historical dates with time. Use Time for modern timestamps.

question_text: What are Ruby's procs
explanation: lambda
youtube_kannada: return from lambda. Procs don't check arity
youtube_tamil: return from enclosing method. Blocks are Proc objects.

question_text: Explain Ruby's URI and Net::HTTP modules
explanation: REST
topic: URI parses URLs. Net::HTTP makes HTTP requests. Use with OpenTimeout and ReadTimeout. Consider HTTParty for simpler API.

question_text: What is Ruby's YAML and Psych for configuration?
explanation: serialization
topic: YAML is human-readable serialization. Psych is Ruby's YAML parser. Use YAML.load_file for config. Security: use safe_load for untrusted data.

question_text: Explain Ruby's JSON parsing and generation
explanation: Oj gem
topic: JSON module provides parse and generate. Oj gem is faster alternative. Use symbolize_names: true for symbol keys.

question_text: What are Ruby's singleton methods on literals?
explanation: integers
youtube_english: nil can have singleton methods but they affect all instances. Strings can have real singleton methods.

question_text: Explain Ruby's const_missing and const_set
explanation: const_missing called when constant not found. Can autoload or create constants dynamically. Use const_set to define.

question_text: What is Ruby's Benchmark module for performance testing?
explanation: Benchmark measures code execution time. bmbm for rehearse mode. benchmark-ips gem for iterations per second.

question_text: Explain Ruby's SecureRandom for cryptography
explanation: tokens
topic: SecureRandom provides cryptographically secure random numbers: random_bytes

question_text: What are Ruby's Tempfile and StringIO for I/O?
explanation: Tempfile creates temporary files auto-deleted. StringIO provides file interface to strings. Useful for testing.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Digest module for hashing
explanation: SHA256
youtube_hindi: SHA256. Use SHA256 for security. For passwords

question_text: What is Ruby's OpenSSL module for SSL/TLS?
explanation: encryption

question_text: Explain Ruby's Socket programming basics
explanation: server-client
topic: Socket provides low-level network programming. TCPSocket for TCP
mdn_link: UDPSocket for UDP. Use with IO.select for multiplexing.

question_text: What are Ruby's IRB and Pry for REPL and debugging?
explanation: debugging
mdn_link: IRB is Ruby's built-in REPL. Pry is enhanced with syntax highlighting
youtube_hindi: source browsing. Use binding.pry for debugger.

question_text: Explain Ruby's RDoc and Yard for documentation
explanation: RDoc is built-in documentation generator. Yard is modern alternative with better features and @tag syntax.

question_text: What is Ruby's RubyVM module and MRI internals?
explanation: RubyVM provides access to MRI internals: instruction sequences

question_text: Explain Ruby's did_you_mean gem for error suggestions
explanation: did_you_mean suggests similar method/constant names on NameError. Included in Ruby 2.3+. Improves developer experience.

question_text: What are Ruby's refinements with prepend and super?
correct_answer: Refinements can call super to invoke original method. prepend works with refinements but complex. Use for layered modifications.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/refinements_rdoc.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's Module#nesting and lexical scope
explanation: Module.nesting returns current lexical scope chain. Used for constant lookup. Differs from Module.nesting which is dynamic.

question_text: What is Ruby's TracePoint for profiling and debugging?
explanation: TracePoint can profile line executions
topic: method calls. Use :line event for line profiling

question_text: Explain Ruby's Ractor messaging and shareable objects
explanation: take
mdn_link: Ractors communicate via send/yield and take. Only shareable objects (frozen
youtube_english: special classes) can be sent. Copying for others.

question_text: What are Ruby's endless ranges and beginless ranges?
explanation: Endless: (1..). Beginless: (..10). 3-dot excludes end. Useful for slicing and infinite sequences.

question_text: Explain Ruby's pattern matching with case/in
explanation: array/hash matching
topic: Ruby 2.7+ supports pattern matching: case value; in pattern. Deconstructs arrays/hashes. Use for complex conditional logic.

question_text: What is Ruby's numbered parameters and block parameters?
explanation: block parameters
mdn_link: _2 etc are numbered block parameters in Ruby 2.7+. Use for concise blocks: array.map { _1 * 2 }.

question_text: Explain Ruby's method reference operator ::
explanation: Ruby 2.7+: method reference with :. :object.method returns callable object. Useful for passing methods as arguments.

question_text: What are Ruby's endless methods and one-liners?
correct_answer: Endless methods: def method = expression. One-line method definition returning expression. Clean for simple methods.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/methods_rdoc.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's non-ASCII identifiers and encoding
explanation: Ruby supports UTF-8 identifiers: methods
mdn_link: classes. Use # encoding: utf-8 comment. Be careful with Unicode normalization.

question_text: What is Ruby's flip-flop operator and its use?
explanation: Flip-flop: true when left true until right true. Rarely used. Example: (1..10).select { |i| i == 3 .. i == 7 }.

question_text: Explain Ruby's retry
explanation: redo
youtube_english: Retry restarts entire iteration. Redo repeats current iteration. Next skips to next iteration. Break exits loop.

question_text: What are Ruby's BEGIN and END blocks?
explanation: BEGIN runs before main program. END runs after program. Use for initialization/cleanup. Multiple blocks execute in definition order.

question_text: Explain Ruby's alias vs alias_method
explanation: alias creates method alias at parse time. alias_method at runtime. Use alias_method for dynamic aliasing.

question_text: What is Ruby's defined? operator and its return values?
explanation: defined? checks if expression defined. Returns nil if not
topic: or description string. Use for safe method/constant checking.

question_text: Explain Ruby's __FILE__ and __LINE__ constants
explanation: source location
topic: __FILE__ is current file path. __LINE__ is current line number. __dir__ is directory of __FILE__.

question_text: What are Ruby's $SAFE levels and taint checking?
explanation: safe levels
topic: $SAFE levels (0-4) restrict operations. Taint marks untrusted objects. Removed in Ruby 3. Use alternative security measures.

question_text: Explain Ruby's ARGF for command-line file processing
explanation: ARGF reads from files specified in ARGV or stdin if no files. Treats multiple files as single stream. Use for filters.

question_text: What is Ruby's DATA constant and __END__?
explanation: __END__ marks end of code. DATA is File object for data after __END__. Use for embedding data in script.

question_text: Explain Ruby's at_exit for program cleanup
explanation: at_exit registers blocks to run at program exit. Multiple handlers execute in reverse order. Use for resource cleanup.

question_text: What are Ruby's caller and caller_locations?
explanation: Caller returns current call stack as strings. Caller_locations returns Thread::Backtrace::Location objects with more info.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Rational and Complex numbers
explanation: Rational: fractions (1/3r). Complex: imaginary numbers (1+2i). Use for precise math and scientific computing.

question_text: What is Ruby's Matrix class for linear algebra?
explanation: Matrix class provides matrix operations: multiplication
mdn_link: determinants. Use for scientific and ML computations.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Prime class for number theory
explanation: Prime class provides prime number operations: checking
mdn_link: factorization. Use for cryptography and algorithms.

question_text: What are Ruby's forwardable and delegate modules?
explanation: Forwardable provides def_delegator for method forwarding. DelegateClass creates delegator class. Use for composition over inheritance.

question_text: Explain Ruby's singleton module for singleton pattern
correct_answer: Singleton module mixes in singleton behavior. Use require 'singleton' and include Singleton. Provides instance method.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-3.1.2/libdoc/singleton/rdoc/Singleton.html

question_text: What is Ruby's observer pattern implementation?
correct_answer: Observable module provides observer pattern. Use require 'observer' and include Observable. Notify observers on change.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-3.1.2/libdoc/observer/rdoc/Observable.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's timeout module for execution limits
explanation: Timeout module limits block execution time. Raises Timeout::Error. Use for preventing hanging operations.

question_text: What are Ruby's English library for readable aliases?
explanation: English library provides readable names for Perl-style variables: $INPUT_RECORD_SEPARATOR for $/.

question_text: Explain Ruby's getoptlong for command-line parsing
explanation: GetoptLong parses command-line options with long/short forms. Similar to GNU getopt. Use for CLI tools.

question_text: What is Ruby's optparse for option parsing?
explanation: OptionParser provides declarative option parsing with automatic help. More Ruby-ish than GetoptLong. Use for complex CLIs.

question_text: Explain Ruby's fileutils for file operations
explanation: FileUtils provides Unix-like file operations: cp
youtube_hindi: etc. Use for cross-platform file management.

question_text: What are Ruby's pathname for path manipulation?
explanation: Pathname provides object-oriented path manipulation. Use / for path joining

question_text: Explain Ruby's find module for directory traversal
explanation: Find module traverses directories: Find.find('dir') { |f| ... }. Use for recursive file operations.

question_text: What is Ruby's benchmark-ips for performance measurement?
explanation: benchmark-ips gem measures iterations per second. More accurate than Benchmark for microbenchmarks.

question_text: Explain Ruby's memory_profiler for memory analysis
explanation: memory_profiler gem profiles memory allocations. Reports allocations by gem

question_text: What are Ruby's stackprof and flamegraphs?
explanation: stackprof gem provides sampling profiler. flamegraph generates interactive flamegraphs. Use for performance optimization.

question_text: Explain Ruby's rbtree and sorted containers
explanation: rbtree gem provides red-black tree implementation. Faster than Hash for range queries. Use for sorted data structures.

question_text: What is Ruby's concurrent-ruby for concurrency?
explanation: thread pools
topic: concurrent-ruby gem provides high-level concurrency: promises

question_text: Explain Ruby's celluloid actor framework
explanation: Celluloid gem provides actor model with automatic supervision. Each actor runs in separate thread. Use for concurrent systems.

question_text: What are Ruby's dry-rb and rom-rb for functional programming?
explanation: composition
youtube_english: monads. rom-rb is Ruby object mapper. Use for maintainable code.

question_text: Explain Ruby's hanami framework architecture
explanation: Hanami is full-stack Ruby framework emphasizing clean architecture

question_text: What is Ruby's Grape API framework?
explanation: Grape is REST-like API micro-framework. DSL for defining APIs. Use for building API services.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Sinatra and modular applications
explanation: Rack
topic: Sinatra is DSL for web applications. Supports classic and modular styles. Use Rack middleware. Lightweight alternative to Rails.

question_text: What are Ruby's Rack middleware and builders?
explanation: request processing
topic: Rack is Ruby web server interface. Middleware processes requests in stack. Use Rack::Builder to compose middleware.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Puma and Falcon web servers
explanation: concurrency
topic: Puma is threaded web server. Falcon uses async I/O. Choose based on concurrency model: threads vs fibers.

question_text: What is Ruby's JIT compiler (MJIT) and performance?
explanation: MJIT (Method-based JIT) compiles hot methods to C. Ruby 2.6+ experimental

question_text: Explain Ruby's TruffleRuby and GraalVM
explanation: TruffleRuby runs on GraalVM with peak performance higher than MRI. Uses AST interpretation and Graal JIT. Good for long-running apps.

question_text: What are Ruby's JRuby and Java interoperability?
explanation: JRuby runs Ruby on JVM. Access Java classes directly. Use for Java library integration and JVM performance.

question_text: Explain Ruby's mruby for embedded systems
explanation: Mruby is lightweight Ruby implementation for embedding. No eval

question_text: What is Ruby's RubySpec and language specification?
explanation: RubySpec was community language specification. Now superseded by ruby/spec. Tests Ruby language behavior.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Minitest vs RSpec testing frameworks
explanation: Minitest is built-in
topic: simpler. RSpec has richer DSL for BDD. Choose based on team preference and project needs.

question_text: What are Ruby's factory_bot and fixtures for testing?
explanation: FactoryBot creates test objects with defined factories. Better than fixtures for complex data. Use for test setup.

question_text: Explain Ruby's VCR for HTTP testing
explanation: VCR records HTTP interactions and replays them. Isolates tests from external services. Use for reliable HTTP testing.

question_text: What is Ruby's simplecov for code coverage?
explanation: SimpleCov gem provides code coverage reporting. Integrates with Minitest/RSpec. Generates HTML reports.

question_text: Explain Ruby's rubocop for code linting
explanation: Rubocop enforces Ruby style guide. Auto-correct available. Use for consistent code and catching potential issues.

question_text: What are Ruby's bundler and Gemfile.lock?
explanation: dependency resolution
topic: Bundler manages gem dependencies. Gemfile declares dependencies. Gemfile.lock locks specific versions for reproducibility.

question_text: Explain Ruby's rake for task automation
explanation: Rake is Ruby build tool. Define tasks with dependencies. Use for automation: testing

question_text: What is Ruby's thor for CLI building?
explanation: Thor gem helps build CLI tools with subcommands

question_text: Explain Ruby's zeitwerk code loader
explanation: Zeitwerk is modern code loader for Ruby. Used by Rails 6+. Provides constant autoloading with explicit conventions.

question_text: What are Ruby's dry-transaction and dry-monads?
explanation: dry-transaction provides transaction pattern. dry-monads provides Maybe
mdn_link: Try monads. Use for functional error handling.

question_text: Explain Ruby's trailblazer for business logic
explanation: Trailblazer provides architecture for business logic: operations

question_text: What is Ruby's Pact for consumer-driven contracts?
explanation: Pact implements consumer-driven contracts. Consumers define expectations
topic: providers verify. Use for microservices integration.

question_text: Explain Ruby's sidekiq and background jobs
explanation: Sidekiq uses Redis for job queues. Provides retries
mdn_link: monitoring. Use for async task processing.

question_text: What are Ruby's whenever and clockwork for scheduling?
explanation: Whenever gem provides cron syntax in Ruby. Clockwork runs tasks within Ruby process. Use for scheduled jobs.

question_text: Explain Ruby's devise and authentication
explanation: Devise provides full-featured authentication: registration

question_text: What is Ruby's cancancan and pundit for authorization?
explanation: CanCanCan provides role-based authorization. Pundit uses policy objects. Choose based on complexity needs.

question_text: Explain Ruby's carrierwave and active storage
explanation: CarrierWave is file upload gem. Active Storage is Rails built-in. Choose based on Rails version and needs.

question_text: What are Ruby's kaminari and will_paginate?
explanation: Kaminari and will_paginate provide pagination. Kaminari more feature-rich. Choose based on project requirements.

question_text: Explain Ruby's elasticsearch-ruby and searchkick
explanation: elasticsearch-ruby is low-level client. Searchkick is high-level with ActiveRecord integration. Use for search features.

question_text: What is Ruby's graphql-ruby for GraphQL APIs?
explanation: graphql-ruby implements GraphQL server. Provides type system

question_text: Explain Ruby's money gem for currency handling
explanation: Money gem provides currency handling: arithmetic

question_text: What are Ruby's i18n and localization?
explanation: I18n provides internationalization: locale files

question_text: Explain Ruby's paper_trail for auditing
explanation: PaperTrail tracks changes to models: who
mdn_link: when. Use for audit trails and version history.

question_text: What is Ruby's friendly_id for SEO-friendly URLs?
explanation: FriendlyId creates human-readable URLs from model attributes. Use for better SEO and user experience.

question_text: Explain Ruby's sorbet and type checking
explanation: Sorbet adds static type checking to Ruby. Gradual typing: add types incrementally. Use for large codebases.

question_text: What are Ruby's steep and RBS for type signatures?
explanation: RBS is Ruby type signature language. Steep is type checker using RBS. Use with Sorbet for type safety.

question_text: Explain Ruby's debugger and byebug for debugging
explanation: The debugger gem (Ruby 3.1+) provides debugging. byebug is popular alternative. Use binding.break for breakpoints.

question_text: What is Ruby's ruby-prof for profiling?
explanation: ruby-prof is sampling profiler. Provides call graphs
topic: flat profiles. Use for performance optimization.

question_text: Explain Ruby's celluloid-io for async I/O
explanation: Celluloid-io provides async I/O using celluloid. Reactor pattern for non-blocking operations. Use for high concurrency.

question_text: What are Ruby's concurrent features in Ruby 3?
explanation: Ruby 3 adds Fiber scheduler for async I/O
topic: Ractors for parallelism. Use for high-performance concurrent applications.

question_text: Explain Ruby's pattern matching in case statements
explanation: Ruby 2.7+ supports pattern matching in case: case value; in [x
topic: y] if x > y. Use for complex conditional logic.

question_text: What is Ruby's data class proposal and value objects?
explanation: Data class proposal (Ruby 3.2+) provides simple value objects. Immutable with positional or keyword initialization.

question_text: Explain Ruby's endless method definition syntax
correct_answer: Ruby 3.0+ supports endless methods: def method = expression. Returns expression value. Clean for simple methods.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/methods_rdoc.html

question_text: What are Ruby's numbered block parameters?
explanation: implicit blocks
topic: Ruby 2.7+ supports numbered parameters: array.map { _1 * 2 }. _1 is first parameter

question_text: Explain Ruby's find pattern in pattern matching
explanation: Find pattern in pattern matching: case array; in [*

question_text: What is Ruby's rightward assignment operator?
explanation: Rightward assignment: expression => pattern. Useful in pattern matching and destructuring. Example: {a: 1} => {a:}.

question_text: Explain Ruby's shareable_constant_value pragma
correct_answer: shareable_constant_value pragma makes constants Ractor-shared. Use for frozen arrays/hashes shared between Ractors.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/comments_rdoc.html

question_text: What are Ruby's experimental features and warnings?
correct_answer: Ruby has experimental features with warnings. Use Warning[] to control warnings. Experimental features may change.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Warning.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's RubyVM::AST for abstract syntax trees
explanation: RubyVM::AST provides access to Ruby AST. Use parse
topic: parse_file. Useful for static analysis and code transformation.

question_text: What is Ruby's GC.compact for memory defragmentation?
explanation: GC.compact (Ruby 2.7+) reduces memory fragmentation by moving objects. Improves cache locality and memory usage.

question_text: Explain Ruby's ObjectSpace.dump_all for heap analysis
explanation: ObjectSpace.dump_all writes heap to JSON. Use for debugging memory issues and leak detection.

question_text: What are Ruby's coverage for branch coverage?
explanation: Ruby 3.1+ supports branch coverage. Measures which branches executed in conditionals. Use Coverage.start(branches: true).

question_text: Explain Ruby's Socket.tcp for non-blocking sockets
explanation: Socket.tcp with non-blocking option. Use for timeout control and async connection establishment.

question_text: What is Ruby's OpenURI for simplified HTTP?
explanation: OpenURI extends open to handle HTTP/HTTPS. Simple API but limited features. Use for quick HTTP requests.

question_text: Explain Ruby's StringScanner for parsing
explanation: StringScanner provides lexical scanning. Moves cursor through string. Use for parsing and tokenization.

question_text: What are Ruby's Abbrev and Soundex for text processing?
explanation: Abbrev generates abbreviations. Soundex phonetic matching. Use for autocomplete and name matching.

question_text: Explain Ruby's WeakRef for weak references
explanation: WeakRef doesn't prevent GC of referenced object. Use for caches without memory leaks. Access with WeakRef#__getobj__.

question_text: What is Ruby's TSort for topological sorting?
explanation: TSort provides topological sorting. Use for dependency resolution and task scheduling.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Shellwords for shell escaping
explanation: Shellwords escapes strings for shell commands. Use Shellwords.join for safe command building.

question_text: What are Ruby's Etc and Sys modules for system info?
explanation: user info
topic: Etc provides user/group info. Sys provides system calls. Use for system-level programming.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Fiddle for C extensions
explanation: Fiddle provides FFI to C libraries. Alternative to C extensions. Use for calling C code without compilation.

question_text: What is Ruby's RubyGems and gem building?
explanation: RubyGems manages gem packaging. Use .gemspec file for metadata. Build with gem build

question_text: Explain Ruby's Ruby 3.1 debugger integration
explanation: Ruby 3.1 integrates debugger. Use binding.break for breakpoints. REPL at breakpoint with local variable access.

question_text: What are Ruby's error highlighting in Ruby 3.1?
correct_answer: Ruby 3.1 highlights error location in code. Shows relevant lines and points to error. Improves debugging experience.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/control_expressions_rdoc.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's YJIT in Ruby 3.1+
explanation: YJIT is new JIT compiler in Ruby 3.1 (experimental). Uses LIR (Lightweight IR) and inlines method calls. Faster for Rails.

question_text: What is Ruby's anonymous rest and keyword rest parameters?
explanation: Anonymous rest (*) and keyword rest (**) parameters. **nil explicitly rejects keyword arguments.

question_text: Explain Ruby's pin operator in pattern matching
explanation: Pin operator (^) matches against variable value
topic: not binding. Use in pattern matching to match existing variable.

question_text: What are Ruby's private attr_accessor and friends?
explanation: Private attr_accessor creates private getter/setter. Use private :attr_accessor after definition or private attr_accessor :var.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Module#attr with inheritance
explanation: Module#attr creates getter (and optionally setter). Inherited by subclasses. Redefinable in subclasses.

question_text: What is Ruby's refinement module inclusion?
correct_answer: Refinements can include modules. Included methods become part of refinement. Use for composing refinements.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/refinements_rdoc.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's TracePoint for method coverage
correct_answer: TracePoint :defined_method event fires when method defined. Use for tracking method definitions and meta-programming.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/TracePoint.html

question_text: What are Ruby's Ractor exceptions and error handling?
correct_answer: Ractor exceptions raised in receiver Ractor. Use Ractor.select with move: false to handle exceptions. Isolated error handling.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Ractor.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's frozen string literals pragma
correct_answer: # frozen_string_literal: true makes string literals frozen. Reduces allocations. Use for performance optimization.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/comments_rdoc.html

question_text: What is Ruby's Module#using with arguments?
correct_answer: Module.using activates refinements. Called implicitly with 'using'. Can be called explicitly with module argument.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Module.html#method-i-using

question_text: Explain Ruby's UnboundMethod#bind_call
correct_answer: UnboundMethod#bind_call binds and calls in one operation. More efficient than bind + call separately.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/UnboundMethod.html#method-i-bind_call

question_text: What are Ruby's method parameters with ... (forwarding)?
explanation: ... forwards all arguments (positional
mdn_link: block). Use for delegation and wrapper methods.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Hash#except and #slice
explanation: Hash#except returns hash without specified keys. Hash#slice returns only specified keys. Useful for filtering.

question_text: What is Ruby's Enumerator::Producer for custom enumeration?
correct_answer: Enumerator::Producer (Ruby 2.7+) creates enumerators from blocks. Use for custom iteration logic.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Enumerator/Producer.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's Array#union and #difference
explanation: Array#union combines arrays (unique). Array#difference subtracts elements. Perform set operations on arrays.

question_text: What are Ruby's numbered block local variables?
explanation: _2) act as local variables within block. Can be assigned to

question_text: Explain Ruby's Module#const_source_location
correct_answer: Module#const_source_location returns file and line where constant defined. Useful for debugging and meta-programming.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Module.html#method-i-const_source_location

question_text: What is Ruby's Process.warmup for JIT warmup?
explanation: Process.warmup (Ruby 3.2+) triggers JIT compilation before peak load. Use for warming up JITted code.

question_text: Explain Ruby's Data.define for value objects
explanation: Data.define (Ruby 3.2+) creates immutable value objects. Similar to Struct but immutable with better equality.

question_text: What are Ruby's pattern matching with guards?
correct_answer: Pattern matching supports guards: case value; in pattern if condition. Filters matches based on condition.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/doc/syntax/pattern_matching_rdoc.html

question_text: Explain Ruby's method overriding with prepend
correct_answer: Prepend allows overriding methods and calling super to original. Super calls go up ancestor chain through prepended modules.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Module.html#method-i-prepend

question_text: What is Ruby's Module#ruby2_keywords for keyword args?
correct_answer: Module#ruby2_keywords marks method for Ruby 2.7+ keyword argument compatibility. Use for delegation with older code.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Module.html#method-i-ruby2_keywords

question_text: Explain Ruby's GC.auto_compact= configuration
correct_answer: GC.auto_compact= (Ruby 3+) enables automatic compaction after major GC. Reduces fragmentation over time.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/GC.html#method-c-auto_compact-3D

question_text: What are Ruby's Ractor.make_shareable for object sharing?
correct_answer: Ractor.make_shareable makes object shareable between Ractors. Freezes object and nested objects. Use for shared data.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Ractor.html#method-c-make_shareable

question_text: Explain Ruby's Fiber.schedule for async programming
explanation: Fiber.schedule (Ruby 3+) enables async programming. Scheduler hooks for non-blocking I/O. Use with async gems.

question_text: What is Ruby's ObjectSpace.memsize_of for memory measurement?
correct_answer: ObjectSpace.memsize_of returns memory usage of object including overhead. Useful for profiling memory usage.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/ObjectSpace.html#method-c-memsize_of

question_text: Explain Ruby's Regexp.timeout= for regex security
explanation: Regexp.timeout= sets timeout for regex matching. Prevents ReDoS attacks. Use for security-critical regexes.

question_text: What are Ruby's Module#source_location for methods?
correct_answer: Module#source_location returns file and line where method defined. Useful for debugging and documentation.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Method.html#method-i-source_location

question_text: Explain Ruby's Encoding::Converter for encoding transcoding
explanation: Encoding::Converter converts between encodings with finer control than String#encode. Use for complex encoding handling.

question_text: What is Ruby's Random.urandom for secure randomness?
explanation: Random.urandom returns secure random bytes from OS. More secure than Random.rand for cryptography.

question_text: Explain Ruby's IO::Buffer for high-performance I/O
explanation: IO::Buffer (Ruby 3.1+) provides zero-copy I/O operations. Use for high-performance networking and file I/O.

question_text: What are Ruby's Thread::Backtrace.limit for stack traces?
correct_answer: Thread::Backtrace.limit sets maximum frames in backtrace. Use to reduce memory usage of exceptions.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Thread/Backtrace.html#method-c-limit

question_text: Explain Ruby's Module#const_added hook
correct_answer: Module#const_added called when constant added to module. Use for tracking constant definitions.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/Module.html#method-i-const_added

question_text: What is Ruby's TracePoint for RubyVM instructions?
correct_answer: TracePoint :script_compiled event fires when code compiled to instructions. Use for VM-level profiling.
explanation: https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.2/TracePoint.html
